results.abstract: Six astronauts, including four remaining Mercury 7, gather at Johnson Space Center in Houston to pay tribute to Alan B Shepard Jr, who led them all into space; more than 850 NASA employees, guests and members of public attend one-hour ceremony; photo (M)

headline.main: Mercury Crew Bids Farewell To Colleague, Alan Shepard

results.snippet: Six astronauts, including the four remaining Mercury 7, gathered here today to pay tribute to Alan B. Shepard Jr., who led them all into space.    ''Alan Shepard was many things,'' recalled Senator John Glenn, one of the Mercury astronauts. ''He was...
results.lead_paragraph: Six astronauts, including the four remaining Mercury 7, gathered here today to pay tribute to Alan B. Shepard Jr., who led them all into space. ''Alan Shepard was many things,'' recalled Senator John Glenn, one of the Mercury astronauts. ''He was a patriot, he was a leader, he was a competitor, a fierce competitor. He was a hero. Most importantly to us, he was a close friend.''

results.abstract: Excerpts of interview with Anthony D Vitulli, official photographer for Westchester County, NY; photo (M)

headline.main: Q&A/Anthony D. Vitulli; Photographer of Record for the County

results.snippet: ALAN SHEPARD'S recent death could not help evoking memories for Anthony D. Vitulli, the ubiquitous photographer for Westchester County. Mr. Vitulli of Cortlandt Manor  was one of nine photographers picked by the United States Navy in 1961 to...
results.lead_paragraph: ALAN SHEPARD'S recent death could not help evoking memories for Anthony D. Vitulli, the ubiquitous photographer for Westchester County. Mr. Vitulli of Cortlandt Manor was one of nine photographers picked by the United States Navy in 1961 to photograph the astronaut. These days, Mr. Vitulli's photographs are less historic -- parks, accidents, important events -- taken from hot-air balloons, blimps, boats, office buildings and hotels.

results.abstract: Antiques column on large price being paid for whirligigs, early American folk art toys; photo (M)
results.snippet: On Sunday, Skinner Inc. of Boston auctioned off an Uncle Sam whirligig, or wind toy, for $12,650 at its sale of American Furniture and Decorative Arts. In fine condition, the 72-inch-tall carved wood and sheet-metal sculpture depicts Uncle Sam sawing...
results.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Skinner Inc. of Boston auctioned off an Uncle Sam whirligig, or wind toy, for $12,650 at its sale of American Furniture and Decorative Arts. In fine condition, the 72-inch-tall carved wood and sheet-metal sculpture depicts Uncle Sam sawing a log resting on a sawbuck. Standing beneath a flagpole, Stars and Stripes flapping away, this Uncle Sam is quite the dandy. He has long, wavy blond hair and wears bold red-and-white striped pants, a long blue tail coat and a white top hat with a star-studded blue hatband. He braces his foot on a log meticulously painted to show individual rings of growth. The log moves back and forth as the wind hits an elaborate mechanism underneath, a carousel of wind paddles. Commenting on its complex design, Stephen Fletcher, the head of Skinner's Americana department, said, ''It must have been made by an engineer-savant.''

results.snippet: Seeing Stars    Q. Why can't you see the stars in photos or videos taken by astronauts?    A. Such pictures do not ordinarily show stars because the stars are not bright enough in comparison with the nearby Sun and the things it shines on.
results.lead_paragraph: Seeing Stars Q. Why can't you see the stars in photos or videos taken by astronauts? A. Such pictures do not ordinarily show stars because the stars are not bright enough in comparison with the nearby Sun and the things it shines on.

headline.main: Society Organizes to Make a Case for Humans on Mars

results.snippet: BRIAN BARNWELL has a nose for historical events. In 1955, he attended the splashy opening of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. In 1969, he visited Florida to witness the launching of Apollo 11, which sent men to land on the Moon.     And, last week, Mr....
results.lead_paragraph: BRIAN BARNWELL has a nose for historical events. In 1955, he attended the splashy opening of Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. In 1969, he visited Florida to witness the launching of Apollo 11, which sent men to land on the Moon. And, last week, Mr. Barnwell, a 52-year-old real estate appraiser from Santa Barbara, Calif., took his sons, 14-year-old Brendan and 10-year-old Sean, to Boulder, Colo., for another special moment in the chronicles of American culture -- the founding convention of the Mars Society, a group of people who fervently believe it possible to send humans to Mars with existing technology at an affordable cost if only the American people will get behind the idea.

results.abstract: Home Video column discusses agreement that convinced Charlton Heston into doing sequel Beneath the Planet of the Apes (1969) for 20th Century Fox; notes this week Fox issued Planet of the Apes in 30th-anniversary edition, along with four sequels and two-hour documentary about the making of all of them; photo (M)

headline.main: Home Video; Chiller Theater For Primates

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: BENEATH THE PLANET OF THE APES (MOVIE)

results.snippet: In 1969, Richard Zanuck was trying hard to sign up Charlton Heston for a sequel being made by 20th Century Fox, which was run by Mr. Zanuck. A year earlier, Mr. Heston had starred as the astronaut Taylor in Fox's highly successful ''Planet of the...
results.lead_paragraph: In 1969, Richard Zanuck was trying hard to sign up Charlton Heston for a sequel being made by 20th Century Fox, which was run by Mr. Zanuck. A year earlier, Mr. Heston had starred as the astronaut Taylor in Fox's highly successful ''Planet of the Apes.'' Now his services were badly needed for ''Beneath the Planet of the Apes,'' the second installment of what would become a five-film series. Mr. Heston, however, felt that for him another ape movie would be one too many. Or at least another complete ape movie. ''I owed Dick one on this,'' he said in an interview this week. ''So I told him, 'I'll be in the first scene, then you kill me.' ''

results.abstract: Peter M Nichols reviews new set of videos from Fox, including documentary, on Planet of the Apes film series; photo (M)

headline.main: In a Social Mirror, The Faces of Apes

results.snippet: EARLY in ''Planet of the Apes,'' the 1968 science-fiction film that spawned four sequels, two television series and all manner of gimcrackery through the 1970's, a tall, lithe astronaut named Taylor corrects the misimpression of two intellectual...
results.lead_paragraph: EARLY in ''Planet of the Apes,'' the 1968 science-fiction film that spawned four sequels, two television series and all manner of gimcrackery through the 1970's, a tall, lithe astronaut named Taylor corrects the misimpression of two intellectual chimpanzees who are trying to determine who this supposedly primitive human is and where he fits into the cosmic puzzle. ''I am not the missing link,'' he informs them. Having crashed-landed a spaceship on an unknown planet he believes to be 320 light years from Earth, Taylor, portrayed with abrasive strength by Charlton Heston, and a cowering band of mutant humans have been rounded up by ferocious gorilla cavalrymen and tossed in a cage as if they were -- well, gorillas.
